title: WCAS HISTORY 260-1-1 History of Latin America in the Colonial Period 1492-1821

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Aspects of the development of Latin America's socioeconomic, political, cultural, and religious institutions and practices from the pre-Columbian and Iberian backgrounds through the colonial period, c. 1492-1821.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two response-type papers based on course content; one research essay of 2,000 words; one exam

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: INSTRUCTOR PROFILE: K. Aaron Van Oosterhout, Ph.D., is a visiting assistant professor at Northwestern University. His research interests include popular religion, the social and political construction of race (particularly for people of African descent in Mexico), and anti-state rebellion. His most recent publication, "Confraternities and Popular Conservatism on the Frontier: Mexico's Sierra del Nayarit in the Nineteenth Century," appeared in The Americas, one of the leading peer-reviewed journals of Latin American studies, in 2014. Outside academia, Aaron serves as the vice-chair of the International Relations Commission for the City of Holland, Michigan, and conducts freelance research work. He is currently working on a project on over-incarceration for the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan.
